Introduction to almanac

Source: vignettes/almanac.Rmd
almanac.Rmd

This vignette is designed to introduce some of the common terminology used in {almanac} to get you up to speed on how to use the package. Along the way, we will see example usage of a number of the building blocks that will allow you to construct more complex schedules.

library(almanac)

Recurrence Rules

A recurrence rule is a structured object that determines if a date should be counted as an event or not. At the most basic level, the job of a recurrence rule is to return TRUE if a particular date is an event, and FALSE otherwise.

To build a recurrence rule, you start with a base recurrence frequency. There are 4 frequencies to choose from:

  • daily()

  • weekly()

  • monthly()

  • yearly()

Take the yearly() frequency, for example. By default, this will declare that 1 value per year is an event.

on_yearly <- yearly()
on_yearly
#> rrule: yearly

The return value of yearly() is a rrule object, short for “recurrence rule”. This base object is all you need to start doing something useful. For example, you can provide sch_seq() this recurrence rule along with a from and to date, and it will return the events that it finds in the date range.

sch_seq("1990-01-01", "1995-12-31", on_yearly)
#> [1] "1990-01-01" "1991-01-01" "1992-01-01" "1993-01-01" "1994-01-01"
#> [6] "1995-01-01"

What if we want a yearly value, but we want it on January 5th every year, rather than on the 1st? yearly() has a very important argument called since that controls two things: the start date of the recurrence rule, and information such as the month, or the day of the month to use for the event dates if no other conditions have been specified to override those.

The default of since is set to 1970-01-01, the Unix epoch, but this is arbitrary. It is because of this default that in the above example with sch_seq() we get values on January 1st. Let’s change that.

on_yearly_jan_5 <- yearly(since = "1990-01-05")

sch_seq("1990-01-01", "1995-12-31", on_yearly_jan_5)
#> [1] "1990-01-05" "1991-01-05" "1992-01-05" "1993-01-05" "1994-01-05"
#> [6] "1995-01-05"

Notice that we also set the since date to be closer to our range of interest. This can dramatically improve performance in some cases.

Now that the since date has been set to 1990, if we try and find yearly dates before 1990, they will not be included.

# same as above, because the 1988 and 1989 dates are not included. 
sch_seq("1988-01-01", "1995-12-31", on_yearly_jan_5)
#> [1] "1990-01-05" "1991-01-05" "1992-01-05" "1993-01-05" "1994-01-05"
#> [6] "1995-01-05"

Recurrence Set

Each recurrence rule comes with its own unique recurrence set. A recurrence set is the set of all event dates that are included in that rule. In the previous example, we used sch_seq() to extract a subset of dates from the recurrence set that were between from and to. You can also check if an existing date is included in a recurrence rule’s set with sch_in().

on_monthly <- monthly(since = "1990-01-10")

x <- as.Date("2000-01-08") + 0:5
x
#> [1] "2000-01-08" "2000-01-09" "2000-01-10" "2000-01-11" "2000-01-12"
#> [6] "2000-01-13"

x_in_set <- sch_in(x, on_monthly)
x_in_set
#> [1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE

x[x_in_set]
#> [1] "2000-01-10"

Caching

{almanac} makes an attempt to be smart by caching dates in the recurrence set that it has “seen”. This means that repeated access to the same schedule can often speed up substantially between the first access and subsequent accesses.

start_date <- "1990-01-01"
on_daily <- daily(since = start_date)

# The first time is "slow"
system.time(sch_seq(start_date, "2000-01-01", on_daily))
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.098   0.005   0.099

# Repeated access to the same location is fast
system.time(sch_seq(start_date, "2000-01-01", on_daily))
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.001   0.000   0.000

# Dates are cached from `[since, to]`, so if you back up `to`, its still fast
system.time(sch_seq(start_date, "1900-05-01", on_daily))
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.001   0.000   0.001

# But when you extend `to` forward in time, it will have to generate all dates
# between `since` and `to` again
system.time(sch_seq(start_date, "2000-05-01", on_daily))
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.076   0.007   0.082

Recurrence Conditions

So far we have worked with the base recurrence rules. Things get much more interesting when we start adding extra conditions to these rules. Conditions are a way to limit or expand a given recurrence rule to hone in on recurring dates that you are particularly interested in. All condition functions in {almanac} start with recur_*(). For example, let’s take a monthly rule, which defaults to give us 1 day per month, and expand it to give us every 4th and 16th day of the month.

on_4th_and_16th <- monthly(since = "2000-01-01") %>%
  recur_on_mday(c(4, 16))

sch_seq("2000-01-01", "2000-06-01", on_4th_and_16th)
#>  [1] "2000-01-04" "2000-01-16" "2000-02-04" "2000-02-16" "2000-03-04"
#>  [6] "2000-03-16" "2000-04-04" "2000-04-16" "2000-05-04" "2000-05-16"

An important thing to note here is that even though our since date is on the first of the month, we are “overriding” that with the recurrence condition, so that information is not used.

Recurrence rules can continually be added to further refine your rule. When you add a condition to a rule, you get another rule back. Let’s try creating a rule for the recurring holiday, Labor Day. This recurs on the first Monday of September, yearly. To do this, we will:

  • Use a yearly() base since this happens 1 time per year.

  • Use recur_on_ymonth() to hone in on September.

  • Use recur_on_wday() to hone in on the first Monday of the month.

on_labor_day <- yearly(since = "2000-01-01") %>%
  recur_on_ymonth("Sep") %>%
  recur_on_wday("Monday", nth = 1)

sch_seq("2000-01-01", "2005-01-01", on_labor_day)
#> [1] "2000-09-04" "2001-09-03" "2002-09-02" "2003-09-01" "2004-09-06"

The nth argument of recur_on_wday() is especially useful for selecting from the end of the month. If we wanted the last Monday in September instead, we could do:

on_last_monday_in_sept <- yearly(since = "2000-01-01") %>%
  recur_on_ymonth("Sep") %>%
  recur_on_wday("Monday", nth = -1)

sch_seq("2000-01-01", "2005-01-01", on_last_monday_in_sept)
#> [1] "2000-09-25" "2001-09-24" "2002-09-30" "2003-09-29" "2004-09-27"

Schedules

Recurrence rules are powerful tools on their own, but they aren’t enough to solve every task. Say you want to construct a rule that includes both Christmas and Labor Day as events. It would be impossible to construct this kind of recurrence set using a single rule, but if you could join multiple rules together, one for Christmas and one for Labor Day, then it would be possible.

A schedule is a collection of recurrence rules. The recurrence set of a schedule is the union of the recurrence sets of every underlying rule. It can also contain specialized dates that you want to forcibly include in the recurrence set, called rdates, and ones that you want to forcibly exclude, called exdates.

on_christmas <- yearly(since = "2000-01-01") %>%
  recur_on_ymonth("Dec") %>%
  recur_on_mday(25)

sch_christmas_or_labor_day <- schedule() %>%
  sch_add_rrule(on_christmas) %>%
  sch_add_rrule(on_labor_day)

sch_seq("2000-01-01", "2002-01-01", sch_christmas_or_labor_day)
#> [1] "2000-09-04" "2000-12-25" "2001-09-03" "2001-12-25"

sch_christmas_or_labor_day_except_2000_labor_day <- sch_christmas_or_labor_day %>%
  sch_add_exdate("2000-09-04")

sch_seq("2000-01-01", "2002-01-01", sch_christmas_or_labor_day_except_2000_labor_day)
#> [1] "2000-12-25" "2001-09-03" "2001-12-25"

Schedules are powerful because they allow us to begin to build up more complicated recurrence sets from simpler pieces. All of the hldy_*() holiday functions are schedules built up from simpler rules. As an example of how complex this can get, take a quick look at hldy_thanksgiving(). In present time, Thanksgiving takes place on the 4th Thursday of November, but it wasn’t always this simple. The date that Thanksgiving occurs on has changed twice, which you can read about here if you are interested, creating the following disjoint set of rules:

  • Pre 1939: Last Thursday in November

  • After 1939 but before 1942: Next to last Thursday in November

  • Post 1942: The 4th Thursday in November

Here is the implementation of hldy_thanksgiving(), which combines these pieces into a larger schedule.

hldy_thanksgiving
#> function (since = "1970-01-01") 
#> {
#>     since <- vec_cast_date(since)
#>     if (since >= as.Date("1942-01-01")) {
#>         return(hldy_thanksgiving_post_1942(since))
#>     }
#>     if (since >= as.Date("1939-01-01")) {
#>         sch <- schedule()
#>         sch <- sch_add_schedule(sch, hldy_thanksgiving_post_1939_pre_1942(since))
#>         sch <- sch_add_schedule(sch, hldy_thanksgiving_post_1942())
#>         return(sch)
#>     }
#>     sch <- schedule()
#>     sch <- sch_add_schedule(sch, hldy_thanksgiving_pre_1939(since))
#>     sch <- sch_add_schedule(sch, hldy_thanksgiving_post_1939_pre_1942())
#>     sch <- sch_add_schedule(sch, hldy_thanksgiving_post_1942())
#>     return(sch)
#> }
#> <bytecode: 0x68e5c08>
#> <environment: namespace:almanac>
